<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: PrintWriter to multiple files: :I need to write the same text to multiple files (or streams).Sometimes I need to use Writer, sometimes a PrintWriter, sometimes a OutputStream...One way to do this wold be to extend a PrintWriter to have an array of PrintWriters and overridde each method as follows:class MutiplePrintWriter extends PrintWriter {    private PrintWriter[] outs;    public MutiplePrintWriter(PrintWriter[] outs) { this.out = out; }    public void print(boolean b) { for (PrintWriter out : outs) print(b); }    public void print(char c) { for (PrintWriter out : outs) print(c); }    public void print(char[] s) { for (PrintWriter out : outs) print(s); }    ...}   (and the same for Writer, OutputStream...)Is there a better alternative?Is this already implemented in a library?
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.
Answer:
response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: PrintWriter to multiple files: :I need to write the same text to multiple files (or streams).Sometimes I need to use Writer, sometimes a PrintWriter, sometimes a OutputStream...One way to do this wold be to extend a PrintWriter to have an array of PrintWriters and overridde each method as follows:class MutiplePrintWriter extends PrintWriter {    private PrintWriter[] outs;    public MutiplePrintWriter(PrintWriter[] outs) { this.out = out; }    public void print(boolean b) { for (PrintWriter out : outs) print(b); }    public void print(char c) { for (PrintWriter out : outs) print(c); }    public void print(char[] s) { for (PrintWriter out : outs) print(s); }    ...}   (and the same for Writer, OutputStream...)Is there a better alternative?Is this already implemented in a library?
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.
Answer: <<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: 
```java
PrintWriter[] pwArray = new PrintWriter[n];
for (int i=0; i<n; i++) {
    pwArray[i] = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter("file" + i + ".txt"));
}

PrintWriter pw = new MutiplePrintWriter(pwArray);
pw.write("Hello, World!");
```
<<<explanation>>>: 
In this code, we first create an array of PrintWriters, each writing to a different file. We then create a new instance of our custom PrintWriter class, passing in the array of PrintWriters. When we call write on this new PrintWriter, it will write the string to each of the files.

This approach is not as efficient as it could be, as it involves a lot of redundant method calls. A more efficient approach would be to extend the PrintWriter class and override the write methods to call the write method on each of the PrintWriters in the array. This would eliminate the need for the for loop in the custom PrintWriter class. However, this would also mean that the write methods in the PrintWriter class would need to be overridden as well, which could lead to a lot of code duplication.

There is no built-in class in Java that does this, but it is not difficult to implement. It would be a good exercise for understanding how to extend classes in Java.

Please note that this code assumes that the files "file0.txt", "file1.txt", etc. do not already exist. If they do, the code will overwrite them.
